intro: Galium mexicanum var. asperrimum, commonly known as Mexican bedstraw, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to parts of Mexico. It belongs to the Rubiaceae family and is characterized by its slender, creeping stems that often root at the nodes. The plant produces small, white or pale yellow flowers arranged in clusters, typically blooming in spring and early summer. Its leaves are opposite, ovate to elliptic in shape, and covered with fine hairs, giving it a slightly rough texture. Galium mexicanum var. asperrimum is often found in moist, shaded environments such as woodlands and stream banks.
